Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2014 03:02PM L60 wrote: I had my surgery on February 6th, so I am two days post op. I am surprised how long it has taken for me to shake the effects of the anesthesia! The surgery lasted less than 1/2 hour, but I am just beginning to feel alert and ready to resume my normal activities...but I am hesitant to push myself. I have had little to know pain from the surgical site, but have lots of pain in my upper arms which has limited my desire to raise my arms. A friend who had a different type of surgery also had this problem and we wonder if it was caused while being moved off the operating table. I would definitely recommend allowing yourself 48-72 hours to recuperate if you do not know how you will react to the anesthesia.
Posts.Title: Recovery for Intraductal Papilloma Surgery? thompeli hawkeyeworried

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2014 06:15PM L60 wrote: Mimikay23--thanks for the suggestion! I did call the surgeon yesterday and they referred me back to my primary care physician. Fortunately, I have been fever free for a week. I have also been in contact with the admitting nurse at the hospital so all are aware of my condition. Thank you for your thoughts and prayers!
Posts.Title: Excision on Thursday but Have a Lingering Cold L60 AZ85048
Excision on Thursday but Have a Lingering Cold L60 AZ85048

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2014 04:35AM L60 wrote: I had my surgery this morning and I am delighted all went well. No one was at all concerned about my lingering productive cough. The surgery was only 1/2 hour and I had a light sedation. I had a lot of head congestion for about 2 hours afterward...don't know if this is typical.  The surgeon said the tissue removed looked normal...I will get the pathology report Monday; what a relief!
Posts.Title: Excision on Thursday but Have a Lingering Cold L60 AZ85048

Posts.Content: L60 wrote: I am scheduled for a terminal duct excision on Thursday but continue to have a runny nose and a productive cough. I will be given The "twilight" form of sedation via IV. Has anyone been able to have surgery with this type of sedation while still having cold symptoms? I am having a intraductal papilloma removed; I know it carries only a low risk for cancer but I have a strong family history of breast cancer and am anxious for the final results. Any information is appreciated!  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Excision on Thursday but Have a Lingering Cold L60 AZ85048

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 04:51AM L60 wrote: Benign! I pray others will receive this news also! My recovery from the surgery to remove an intraductal papilloma has been relatively pain free. The anesthesiologist placed something in the back of my mouth to keep my airways open. That area burned for about 48 hours; it hurt far more than the incision!  My prayers are with everyone who are waiting.
Posts.Title: Excision on Thursday but Have a Lingering Cold L60 AZ85048

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2014 04:43PM L60 wrote: Some woman leave surgery wearing a breast binder...like a tube top with a Velcro fastener. Sine this is adjustable it might be all you need while you recuperate. I did not have one so I cannot comment about how well it works under clothes. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Bras for after lumpectomy? faerywings Annette47

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2014 03:41AM L60 wrote: I was referred back to my primary care physician for her evaluation. She feels I will be ready for surgery on Thursday. I need to continue my antibiotic and begin an inhaler to take care of the residual bronchial issues I have. My fingers are crossed that I will continue to improve and have no problems during the surgery.
